Description: Terracotta figure of crawling infant. A figure of a boy crouching on a low oval plinth: he is seated with his hands supporting his weight in front of him, and his head raised up. He has a side-lock and indications of hair above his brow, and is naked except for a bulla on his breast. His right hand and foot and part of the plinth are lost. It represents a child not yet able to walk and in the early stages of beginning to crawl. Solid and probably hand-modelled, but it may be from a two-piece mould. Micaceous red-brown Nile silt, with a darkgrey core.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV Comparanda. Close: Petrie Museum uc47796. Near: Castiglione et al. 1978: 13, fig. 11, on stool-like base, dated first century bc/ad; Petrie Museum uc47797, from Memphis; Török 1995: no. 221 bis, dated before the first century bc; the female child Fjeldhagen 1995: no. 166, dated late second to third century ad; the clothed and hooded child Breccia 1934: no. 233. The very close Petrie Museum uc16613, with no provenance, carved in limestone, is given a Middle Kingdom date.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3532)
